ACCUSING.usage: The policeman was accusing the man of stealing a wallet.

AFFECTIONATE.usage: Most mothers are affectionate to their babies by giving them lots of kisses and cuddles.

AGHAST.usage: Jane was aghast when she discovered her house had been burgled.

ALARMED.usage: Claire was alarmed when she thought she was being followed home.

AMUSED.usage: I was amused by a funny joke someone told me.

ANNOYED.usage: Jack was annoyed when he found out he had missed the last bus home.

ANTICIPATING.usage: At the start of the football match, the fans were anticipating a quick goal.

ANXIOUS.usage: The student was feeling anxious before taking her final exams.

APOLOGETIC.usage: The waiter was very apologetic when he spilt soup all over the customer.

ARROGANT.definition: conceited, self-important, having a big opinion of oneself
ARROGANT.usage: The arrogant man thought he knew more about politics than everyone else in the room.

ASHAMED.usage: The boy felt ashamed when his mother discovered him stealing money from her purse.

ASSERTIVE.usage: The assertive woman demanded that the shop give her a refund.

BAFFLED.usage: The detectives were completely baffled by the murder case.

BEWILDERED.usage: The child was bewildered when visiting the big city for the first time.

CAUTIOUS.usage: Sarah was always a bit cautious when talking to someone she did not know.

COMFORTING.usage: The nurse was comforting the wounded soldier.

CONCERNED.usage: The doctor was concerned when his patient took a turn for the worse.

CONFIDENT.usage: The tennis player was feeling very confident about winning his match.

CONFUSED.usage: Lizzie was so confused by the directions given to her, she got lost.

CONTEMPLATIVE.usage: John was in a contemplative mood on the eve of his 60th birthday.

CONTENTED.usage: After a nice walk and a good meal, David felt very contented.

CONVINCED.usage: Richard was convinced he had come to the right decision.

CURIOUS.usage: Louise was curious about the strange-shaped parcel.

DECIDING.usage: The man was deciding who to vote for in the election.

DECISIVE.usage: Jane looked very decisive as she walked into the polling station.

DEFIANT.definition: insolent, bold, don’t care what anyone else thinks
DEFIANT.usage: The animal protester remained defiant even after being sent to prison.

DEPRESSED.usage: George was depressed when he didn’t receive any birthday cards.

DESIRE.usage: Kate had a strong desire for chocolate.

DESPONDENT.usage: Gary was despondent when he did not get the job he wanted.

DISAPPOINTED.usage: Manchester United fans were disappointed not to win the Championship.

DISPIRITED.usage: Adam was dispirited when he failed his exams.

DISTRUSTFUL.usage: The old woman was distrustful of the stranger at her door.

DOMINANT.usage: The sergeant major looked dominant as he inspected the new recruits.

DOUBTFUL.usage: Mary was doubtful that her son was telling the truth.

DUBIOUS.usage: Peter was dubious when offered a surprisingly cheap television in a pub.

EAGER.usage: On Christmas morning, the children were eager to open their presents.

EARNEST.usage: Harry was very earnest about his religious beliefs.

EMBARRASSED.usage: After forgetting a colleague’s name, Jenny felt very embarrassed.

ENCOURAGING.usage: All the parents were encouraging their children in the school sports day.

ENTERTAINED.definition: absorbed and amused or pleased by something
ENTERTAINED.usage: I was very entertained by the magician.

ENTHUSIASTIC.usage: Susan felt very enthusiastic about her new fitness plan.

FANTASIZING.usage: Emma was fantasizing about being a film star.

FASCINATED.usage: At the seaside, the children were fascinated by the creatures in the rock pools.

FEARFUL.usage: In the dark streets, the women felt fearful.

FLIRTATIOUS.usage: Connie was accused of being flirtatious when she winked at a stranger at a party.

FLUSTERED.usage: Sarah felt a bit flustered when she realised how late she was for the meeting and that she had forgotten an important document.

FRIENDLY.usage: The friendly girl showed the tourists the way to the town centre.

GRATEFUL.usage: Kelly was very grateful for the kindness shown by the stranger.

GUILTY.definition: feeling sorry for doing something wrong
GUILTY.usage: Charlie felt guilty about having an affair.

HATEFUL.usage: The two sisters were hateful to each other and always fighting.

HOPEFUL.usage: Larry was hopeful that the post would bring good news.

HORRIFIED.usage: The man was horrified to discover that his new wife was already married.

HOSTILE.usage: The two neighbours were hostile towards each other because of an argument about loud music.

IMPATIENT.definition: restless, wanting something to happen soon
IMPATIENT.usage: Jane grew increasingly impatient as she waited for her friend who was already 20 minutes late.

IMPLORING.usage: Nicola looked imploring as she tried to persuade her dad to lend her the car.

INCREDULOUS.usage: Simon was incredulous when he heard that he had won the lottery.

INDECISIVE.definition: unsure, hesitant, unable to make your mind up
INDECISIVE.usage: Tammy was so indecisive that she couldn’t even decide what to have for lunch.

INDIFFERENT.usage: Terry was completely indifferent as to whether they went to the cinema or the pub.

INSISTING.usage: After a work outing, Frank was insisting he paid the bill for everyone.

INSULTING.usage: The football crowd was insulting the referee after he gave a penalty.

INTERESTED.usage: After seeing Jurassic Park, Huge grew very interested in dinosaurs.

INTRIGUED.usage: A mystery phone call intrigued Zoe.

IRRITATED.usage: Frances was irritated by all the junk mail she received.

JEALOUS.usage: Tony was jealous of all the taller, better-looking boys in his class.

JOKING.usage: Gary was always joking with his friends.

NERVOUS.usage: Just before her job interview, Alice felt very nervous.

OFFENDED.usage: When someone made a joke about her weight, Martha felt very offended.

PANICKED.definition: distraught, feeling of terror or anxiety
PANICKED.usage: On waking to find the house on fire, the whole family were panicked.

PENSIVE.usage: Susie looked pensive on the way to meeting her boyfriend’s parents for the first time.

PERPLEXED.usage: Frank was perplexed by the disappearance of his garden gnomes.

PLAYFUL.definition: full of high spirits and fun
PLAYFUL.usage: Neil was feeling playful at his birthday party.

PREOCCUPIED.definition: absorbed, engrossed in one’s own thoughts
PREOCCUPIED.usage: Worrying about her mother’s illness made Debbie preoccupied at work

PUZZLED.usage: After doing the crossword for an hour, June was still puzzled by one clue.

REASSURING.usage: Andy tried to look reassuring as he told his wife that her new dress did suit her.

REFLECTIVE.usage: George was in a reflective mood as he thought about what he’d done with his life.

REGRETFUL.usage: Lee was always regretful that he had never travelled when he was younger.

RELAXED.usage: On holiday, Pam felt happy and relaxed.

RELIEVED.usage: At the restaurant, Ray was relieved to find he had not forgotten his wallet.

RESENTFUL.usage: The businessman felt very resentful towards his younger colleague who had been promoted above him.

SARCASTIC.usage: The comedian made a sarcastic comment when someone came into the theatre late.

SATISFIED.usage: Steve felt very satisfied after he had got his new flat just how he wanted it.

SCEPTICAL.usage: Patrick looked sceptical as someone read out his horoscope to him.

SERIOUS.usage: The bank manager looked serious as he refused Nigel an overdraft.

STERN.usage: The teacher looked very stern as he told the class off.

SUSPICIOUS.usage: After Sam had lost his wallet for the second time at work, he grew suspicious of one of his colleagues.

SYMPATHETIC.usage: The nurse looked sympathetic as she told the patient the bad news.

TENTATIVE.usage: Andrew felt a bit tentative as he went into the room full of strangers.

TERRIFIED.usage: The boy was terrified when he thought he saw a ghost.

THOUGHTFUL.usage: Phil looked thoughtful as he sat waiting for the girlfriend he was about to finish with.

THREATENING.usage: The large, drunk man was acting in a very threatening way.

UNEASY.usage: Karen felt slightly uneasy about accepting a lift from the man she had only met that day.

UPSET.usage: The man was very upset when his mother died.

WORRIED.usage: When her cat went missing, the girl was very worried
